Full text of "Quinquennial catalogue of the officers and graduates of Harvard university, 1636-1895"

See other formats 


This  is  a  digital  copy  of  a  book  that  was  preserved  for  generations  on  library  shelves  before  it  was  carefully  scanned  by  Google  as  part  of  a  project 
to  make  the  world's  books  discoverable  online. 

It  has  survived  long  enough  for  the  copyright  to  expire  and  the  book  to  enter  the  public  domain.  A  public  domain  book  is  one  that  was  never  subject 
to  copyright  or  whose  legal  copyright  term  has  expired.  Whether  a  book  is  in  the  public  domain  may  vary  country  to  country.  Public  domain  books 
are  our  gateways  to  the  past,  representing  a  wealth  of  history,  culture  and  knowledge  that's  often  difficult  to  discover. 

Marks,  notations  and  other  marginalia  present  in  the  original  volume  will  appear  in  this  file  -  a  reminder  of  this  book's  long  journey  from  the 
publisher  to  a  library  and  finally  to  you. 

Usage  guidelines 

Google  is  proud  to  partner  with  libraries  to  digitize  public  domain  materials  and  make  them  widely  accessible.  Public  domain  books  belong  to  the 
public  and  we  are  merely  their  custodians.  Nevertheless,  this  work  is  expensive,  so  in  order  to  keep  providing  this  resource,  we  have  taken  steps  to 
prevent  abuse  by  commercial  parties,  including  placing  technical  restrictions  on  automated  querying. 

We  also  ask  that  you: 

+  Make  non-commercial  use  of  the  files  We  designed  Google  Book  Search  for  use  by  individuals,  and  we  request  that  you  use  these  files  for 
personal,  non-commercial  purposes. 

+  Refrain  from  automated  querying  Do  not  send  automated  queries  of  any  sort  to  Google's  system:  If  you  are  conducting  research  on  machine 
translation,  optical  character  recognition  or  other  areas  where  access  to  a  large  amount  of  text  is  helpful,  please  contact  us.  We  encourage  the 
use  of  public  domain  materials  for  these  purposes  and  may  be  able  to  help. 

+  Maintain  attribution  The  Google  "watermark"  you  see  on  each  file  is  essential  for  informing  people  about  this  project  and  helping  them  find 
additional  materials  through  Google  Book  Search.  Please  do  not  remove  it. 

+  Keep  it  legal  Whatever  your  use,  remember  that  you  are  responsible  for  ensuring  that  what  you  are  doing  is  legal.  Do  not  assume  that  just 
because  we  believe  a  book  is  in  the  public  domain  for  users  in  the  United  States,  that  the  work  is  also  in  the  public  domain  for  users  in  other 
countries.  Whether  a  book  is  still  in  copyright  varies  from  country  to  country,  and  we  can't  offer  guidance  on  whether  any  specific  use  of 
any  specific  book  is  allowed.  Please  do  not  assume  that  a  book's  appearance  in  Google  Book  Search  means  it  can  be  used  in  any  manner 
anywhere  in  the  world.  Copyright  infringement  liability  can  be  quite  severe. 

About  Google  Book  Search 

Google's  mission  is  to  organize  the  world's  information  and  to  make  it  universally  accessible  and  useful.  Google  Book  Search  helps  readers 
discover  the  world's  books  while  helping  authors  and  publishers  reach  new  audiences.  You  can  search  through  the  full  text  of  this  book  on  the  web 

at  http  :  //books  .  google  .  com/| 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


itized  by  Google

Digitized  by  VjOOQIC

Quinquennial  Catalogue 


U^   THE 


OFFICERS  AND  GRADUATES 

OP    ^-^^cy 

HARVARD    UNIVERSITY 

1636-189^ 


CAMBRIDGE.    MASSACHUSETTS 
)PuiiIt0f)eb  bg  ti)e  QBn&ersitg 

IN  THE  I'WO  HUNDRED  AND    FIFTY-NINTH    YEAR  OF  THE  COLLEGE 

FOR  SALE  BY  CHARLES  W.  SEVER 

189s 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


John  Wilson  and  Son,  Cambridge 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


CONTENTS. 


FAGB 

THE   FOUNDING   OF   HARVARD   COLLEGE 5 

THE  BEQUEST  OF  JOHN   HARVARD      ^     .     . 7 

THE   FIRST   MEETING  OF  THE  OVERSEERS 8 

OFFICERS   OF   INSTRUCTION   AND   GOVERNMENT,— 

Presidents 9 

Acting-Presidents • lo 

Fellows 10 

Treasurers 13 

Overseers 14 

Secretaries  of  the  Board  of  Overseers 20 

Professors 21 

Curators  and  Directors 33 

Tutors 35 

Instructors      .    • 40 

Preachers  to  the  University 50 

Lecturers ^i 

Demonstrators 55 

Assistants 56 

Deans 63 

Secretary  of  the  University 64 

Librarians 64 

Stewards  and  Bursars 66 

NOTE 67 

GRADUATES,  — 

Bachelors  of  Arts 69 

Doctors  of  Medicine 251 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


iv  CONTENTS. 

PAGB 

Doctors  of  Dental  Medicine 294 

Doctors  of  Veterinary  Medicine 298 

Bachelors  of  Agricultural  Science 299 

Bachelors  of  Laws 300 

Bachelors  of  Science 336 

Civil  and  Mining  Engineers 343 

Alumni  of  the  Divinity  School  -and  Bachelors  of  Divinity    .     ,  344 
Doctors  of  Philosophy,   Doctors  of  Sqence,  and  Masters  of 

Arts,  who  received  their  degrees  after  examination      .    .  354 

HOLDERS  OF   HONORARY   DEGREES 367 

SUMMARY 405 

INDEX  OF   OFFICERS 407 

INDEX  OF   GRADUATES 421 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


Colony  of  finaissiatf^usitttsi  isav* 

HENRY  VANE,  Governor. 

1636 

At  the  Generall  Court, 

HOULDEN  at  BOSTON,   SEPTEMBER  8™. 

Adjourned  Meetings  October^  28**. 

The  Court  agreed  to  give  400/  towards  a  schoale  or  coUedge,  whearof  200/  to  bee 
paid  the  next  yeare,  &  200/  when  the  worke  is  finished,  &  the  next  Court  to  appoint 
wheare  &  w'  building./    Records  of  Massachusetts  (edited  by  Dr.  ShurtlefT),  i.  183. 


JOHN   WINTHROP,   Governor. 

1637 

A  Generall  Court, 

HELD  AT  NeWETOWNE,  THE  2™   DAY  OF  THE  9^"   M«>. 

Adjourned  meetings  November  1 5'*. 
The  colledg  is  ordered  to  bee  at  Newetowne./    Records  of  Massachusetts,  I.  208. 

Adjourned  meetings  November  20'*. 

For  the  coUedge,  the  Governo',  M'  Winthrope,  the  Deputy,  M'  Dudley,  the  Treas- 
urer, M'  Bellingham,  M'  Humfrey,  M'  Herlakenden,  M'  Staughton,  M'  Cotton,  M' 
Wilson,  M'  Damport,  M'  Wells,  M'  Sheopard,  &  M'  Peters,  these,  or  the  greater  part 
of  them,  whereof  M'  Winthrope,  M'  Dudley,  or  M'  Bellingham,  to  bee  alway  one,  to 
take  order  for  a  coUedge  at  Newetowne./    Records  of  Massachusetts^  i.  217. 

1638 

A  Generall  Court, 
HELD  AT  Newetowne,  the  2°  Day  of  the  3»  Mo,  (May). 
It  is  ordered,  that  Newetowne  shall  henceforward  be  called  Cambrige./    Records 
of  Massachusetts,  i.  228. 

X638/9 

A  Generall  Courte, 

HOULDEN  at  BoSTON,  THE   I3™  OF  THE  FiRST   MoNTH,  (MARCH). 

It  is  ordered,  that  the  colledge  agreed  vpon  formerly  to  bee  built  at  Cambridg 
shalbee  called  Harvard  CoUedge/.    Records  of  Massachusetts,  1.  253. 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


HARVARD  COLLEGE^ 

1642. 

An  act  establishing  the  Overseers  of  Harvard  College. 

1650. 

First  Charter,  still  in  force,  establishing  the  Corporation  of  the  President  and  Fellows 
of  Harvard  College.     (Preserved  in  the  College  Library.) 

1657- 

Appendix  to  the  Charter,  ordering  the  relations  of  the  Overseers  and  the  Corporation. 

1693.    . 

A  new  Charter,  creating  eight  Fellows,  accepted  by  the  College,  but  not  approved  by 
the  King. 

1697. 
A  third  Charter,  creating  fourteen  Fellows,  five  being  Councillors  of  the  Province,  ac- 
cepted by  the  College,  but  not  approved  by  the  King.     (Preserved  in  the  College 
Library.) 

170a 

A  fourth  Charter,  omitting  Councillors  from  the  Corporation,  not  approved  by  the  King. 

1707. 
The  first  Charter  declared  to  be  still  in  force. 

X780. 

The  ancient  rights  and  privileges  of  the  University  at  Cambridge  recognized  by  the 
Constitution  of  the  Commonwealth  of  Massachusetts. 

x8zo. 

The  Board  of  Overseers  reorganized ;  elective  members  introduced. 

X8X2. 

An  act  restoring  the  organization  of  the  Board  of  Overseers  as  it  existed  before  1810, 
not  accepted  by  the  College. 

18x4. 
An  act  repealing  the  act  of  1812,  thus  reestablishing  the  Board  of  Overseers  of  1810. 

1843- 

Clergymen  of  all  denominations  made  eligible  as  Overseers. 

x8sx. 

Reorganization  of  the  Board  of  Overseers ;  limited  term  of  service  introduced. 

X865. 

The  election  of  Overseers  transferred  to  the  Bachelors  and  Master  of  Arts,  and  the 
Honorary  Graduates. 

x88o. 
Persons  not  inhabitants  of  Massachusetts  made  eligible  as  Overseers. 

X889. 

The  manner  of  voting  for  Overseers  simplified  and  the  powers  of  the  Corporation 
enlarged. 
6 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


THE  BEQUEST  OF  JOHN  HARVARD. 


1.

ACTING  PRESIDENTS.  — FELLOWS. 


ACTING  PRESIDENTS. 

Appointed  during  vacancies  to  perform  the  duties  of  the  office,  excepting  such  as 
belong  to  the  President  as  a  member  of  the  Corporation.^ 

1654      The  Fellows  (Tutors)  of  the  College 1654 

1681      The  Fellows  (Tutors)  of  the  College 1682

1663      Samuel  Eliot 1664 

1  President  Oakes  and  President  Mather,  attended  meetings  of  the  Corporation  while  serving  as  acting 
Presidents,  being  in  fact  Presidents  in  all  but  the  form  of  election,  and  their  full  term  of  service  is  recorded 
on  the  preceding  page. 

No  action  in  this  respect  is  recorded  during  the  vacancies  occurring  betweca  the  terms  of  Presidents 
Chaancy  and  Hoar  (1671-1672),  and  Vice-President^Willard  and  President  Leverett  (i707>i7o8). 

Persons  appointed  to  presidb  at  Commencement  during  Vacancies  in  the 

President's  Office.

TREASURERS. 

1834  James  Walker 1853 

^837  John  Amory  Lowell 1877

OVERSEERS. 


OVERSEERS. 

1642. 

**  The  Governor  and  Deputy  Governor  for  the  time  being,  and  all  the  magistrates 
of  this  jurisdiction,  together  with  the  teaching  elders  of  the  six  next  adjoining  towns, 
viz.  Cambridge,  Watertown,  Charlestown,  Boston,  Roxbury,  and  Dorchester,  and  the 
President  of  the  College  for  the  time  being."  *    Order  of  September  27,  1642. 

X697,  1700, 

The  Governor  and  Council  for  the  time  being.* 

1707, 
The  organization  established  in  1642  restored.     Resolve  of  December  6,  1707. 

1780. 

The  Governor^  Lieutenant-Governor y  Council^  and  Senate  of  the  Commonwealth, 
with  the  President  of  the  College,  for  the  time  being,  and  the  Ministers  of  the  Con- 
gregational Churches  in  the  towns  of  Cambridge,  Watertown,  Charlestown,  Boston, 
Roxbury,  and  Dorchester.  Constitution  of  Massachusetts^  ch,  V.  sec.  i.  art.  3  {^une 
IS,  1780). 

i8ia 

IXit  Governor^  Lieutenant-Governor^  Council^  President oi  Xht  Senate,  and  Speaker 
of  the  House  of  Representatives  of  the  Commonwealth,  and  the  President  of  the 
College,  for  the  time  being,  with  fifteen  Ministers  of  Congregational  Churches,  and 
the  following  persons  by  election.  Act  of  March  6,  1810 :  accepted  by  the  President 
and  Fellows^  March  16;  by  the  Overseers^  April  12.* 

1810    Christopher  Gore 1815 

1810    Isaac  Rand 1815 

1810    William  Phillips 1827 

1  '*Over  the  Colledge  are  twelve  Overseers  chosen  by  the  General  Court,  ax  of  them  are  of  the 
Magbtrates,  the  other  six  of  the  Ministers,  who  are  to  promote  the  best  good  of  it,  and  (having  a  power 
of  influence  into  all  persons  in  it)  are  to  see  that  every  one  be  diligent  and  proficient  in  his  proper 
place."  —  New  England's  First  Fruits  (London,  1643)  page  13. 

3  The  Charter  of  1692,  which,  though  duly  passed  l^  the  legishiture,  was  neither  approved  by  the 
King  nor  accepted  by  the  College,  made  no  provision  whatever  for  a  bosird  of  Overseers  or  Visitors,  all 
power  being  placed  in  the  Corporation. 

The  Charter  of  1697  was  likewise  returned  without  approval  by  the  King,  but  the  College  was  for  a 
period  conducted  under  its  provisions.  The  Governor  and  Council  were  to  "  have,  use,  and  exercise  a 
power  of  visitation  as  there  shall  be  occasion  for  it,"  but  their  relation  to  the  Corporation  was  not  defined 
with  exactness. 

The  bill  of  1699,  which  was  not  signed  by  Governor  Bellamont,  assigned  the  power  of  visitation  to  the 
^  King  and  his  Governor.'' 

The  Charter  of  1700,  which,  like  that  of  1697,  was  for  a  time  acknowledged  by  the  CoUqie,  though 
not  approved  by  the  King,  reserved  a  power  of  visitation  to  the  Governor  and  Council. 

s  Fifteen  laymen  were  to  be  elected,  upon  acceptance  of  the  act,  by  the  old  Board  of  Overseers,  and 
were  so  elected,  May  10, 18 10 ;  the  fifteen  ministers  already  members  of  the  Board  continued  in  office. 
Members  were  to  hold  office  so  long  as  they  remained  inhabitants  of  the  State,  unless  removed  by  the 
Board  for  cause ;  but  a  minister  who  ceased  to  hold  the  ministerial  relation  he  held  when  the  act  was 
accepted,  or  at  the  time  of  his  election,  thereby  vacated  his  place  in  the  Board.  The  Board  was  empow- 
ered to  elect  new  members  to  fill  vacancies  occurring  among  either  dass. 

14 


Digitized  by  V^OOQIC

1  The  Act  of  1810  (March  6)  was  repealed  by  an  act  of  Febniary  29, 1812,  and  the  Board  of  Overseers 
re-establ'ished  as  it  had  existed  prior  to  1810.  The  validity  of  the  Act  of  i8ia,  which  did  not  provide  for 
Submission  of  the  Act  to  the  Corporation  and  Overseen  for  their  approval,  was  denied  by  these  bodies ; 
but  it  was  regarded  as  inexpedient  to  press  the  point,  and  the  restored  Board  conducted  business  from 
June  3, 181 2,  until  the  re-establishment  of  the  Board  of  1810  by  the  Act  of  February  28,  1814.

PROFESSORS. 


PROFESSORS. 

THEOLOGY. 

The  Hollis  Professorship  of  Divinity  was  founded  by  Thomas  HoUis  in  1721 ;  the  Bussey  Professorship 
of  Theology  was  established  in  18691  under  the  bequest  of  Benjamin  Bussey  ;  the  Parkman  Professorship 
of  Theology  before  1869  was  known  as  the  Parkman  Professorship  of  Pulpit  Eloquence  and  the  Pastoral 
Care 

1 72 1  Edward  Wiggles  worth,  Hollis 1765 

1 765  Edward  Wigglesworth,  Hollis 1 791 

1 791  Edward  Wigglesworth, -ffjw^rrV«j 1794 

1792  David  Tappan,  Hollis 1803 

1805  Henry  Ware,  Hollis 1840 

1840  Henry  Ware,  Emeritus 1845 

1857  0^oxg^^dyi^x^YXi\%SysUmatic  Theology 1863 

1 867  James  Freeman  Clarke,  Natural  Religion  and  Christian  Doctrine  187 1 

1 869  Charles  Carroll  Everett,  Bussey 

1869      Oliver  Stearns,  Parkman 1878 

1 88 1  Francis  Greenwood  Peabody,  Parkman 1886 

1882  David  Gordon  Lyon,  Hollis 

ECCLESIASTICAL  HISTORY. 

The  Winn  Professorship  was  endowed  in  1877  under  the  will  of  Jonathan  B.  Winn. 

1857      Frederic  Henry  Hedge 1876 

1882      Ephraim  Emerton,  Winn 

SACRED  LITERATURE. 

In  1S19  the  title  of  the  Dexter  Lectureship  on  Biblical  Criticism  (page  46)  was  changed  to  Dexter 
Professorship  of  Sacred  Literature ;  in  1840,  as  the  Dexter  Lectureship  on  Biblical  Literature,  it  was 
united  with  the  Hancock  Professorship  of  Hebrew  and  other  Oriental  Languages. 

The  Bussey  Professorship  of  New  Testament  Criticism  and  Interpretation  was  founded  in  1872,  under 
the  bequest  of  Benjamin  Bussey,  who  died  in  1842. 

1819  Andrews  Norton,  Dexter 1830 

1830  John  Gorham  Palfrey,  i5i3//Va/ Z//^r<i/j#r^ 1839 

1872  Ezra  Abbot,  i5«jj<y 1884 

1884  Joseph  Henry  Thayer,  Bussey 

PULPIT  ELOQUENCE  AND  THE  PASTORAL  CARE. 

The  Professorship  was  established  in  1829,  upon  a  fund  raised  by  friends  of  the  College.  In  1840  it 
was  founded  anew  by  a  union  of  donations  from  Samuel  Parkman,  Francis  Parkman,  George  Partridge, 
and  Eliphalet  Pearson,  and  entitled  the  Parkman  Professorship.  In  1869  the  title  was  changed  to 
Parkman  Professorship  of  Theology. 

1829     Henry  Ware,  Jr.,  after  1840  Parkman 1842 

1842      Convers  Francis,  Parkman 1863 

1863     Oliver  Steams, /'jri^Mjff 1869 

21 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


PROFESSORS. 

CHRISTIAN   MORALS. 

The  professorship  was  founded  in  1S55,  hy  the  will  of  Caroline  Plummer,  the  full  title  of  the  incum- 
bent being  **  Preacher  to  the  University  and  Plummer  Professor  of  Christian  Morals; "  in  1886  the  title 
was  changed  to  **  Plummer  Professor  of  Christian  Morals."    See  page  45. 

1855  Frederic  Dan  Huntington i860 

i860  Andrew  Preston  Peabody 1881 

1 88 1  Andrew  Preston  Peabody,  Eftteritus 1893 

1886  Francis  Greenwood  Peabody 

^PHILOSOPHY. 

The  Alford  Professorship  of  Natural  Religion,  Moral  Philosophy,  and  Civil  Polity  was  endowed  in  1789, 
by  Edmund  Trowbridge  and  Richard  Cary,  executors  of  the  will  of  John  Alford,  who  died  in  1761. 

1817  Levi  Frisbie,  Alford 1822 

1827  Levi  Hedge,  Alford 1832 

1838  James  Walker, -4^^r^ 1853 

1853  Francis  Bowen,  Alford 1889 

1867  Ephraim  Whitman  Gurney,  AssL  Prof  Intellectual  Philosophy  1868 

1870  Ellis  Peterson,  Assistant  Professor 1872 

1873  George  Herbert  Palmer,  Assistant  Professor 1883

1883      George  Herbert  Palmer 1889 

1885      William  James 1889 

1885  J osxah  Royce,  Assistant  Professor 1892 

1889      Francis  Bowen,  Alford^  Emeritus 1890 

1889      George  Herbert  Palmer,  Alford 

1889     William  James,  Psychology 

1892     Josiah  Royce,  History  of  Philosophy 

1892      Hugo  Miinsterberg,  Experimental  Psychology 

POLITICAL  ECONOMY. 

1 871  Charles  Franklin  Dunbar

LAW. 

The  Royall  Professorship  was  established  in  181 5,  under  the  will  of  Isaac  Royall,  who  died  in  1781. 
The  University  Professorship  was  established  in  1817;  in  1S62  the  title  was  changed  to  Bussey  Pro- 
fessorship. The  Dane  Professorship  was  founded  in  1829  by  Nathan  Dane  (H.  C.  1778).  The  Story 
Professorship  was  established  m  1875,  and  named  in  honor  of  Joseph  Story  (H.  C.  i7<>8).  A  chair 
was  founded  in  i88a  by  Wm.  F.  Weld,  Jr.  (H.  C.  1876)  ;  by  his  wish  the  giver  was  not  made  known 
until  his  death.     In  1893  the  chair  was  entitled  the  Weld  Professorship  of  Law. 

181 5     Isaac  Parker,  ^/y«// 1827 

1 81 7    Asahel  Stearns,  University 1829

GREEK  LITERATURE. 

The  Professorship  of  Greek  Literature  was  founded  in  18 14  by  an  unknown  benefactor.  Upon  the 
death  of  Samuel  Eliot,  in  i8ao,  the  Corporation  were  informed  that  he  bad  been  the  founder,  and  the  chair 
was  named  the  Eliot  Professorship  of  Greek  Literature.

PROFESSORS. 

CHEMISTRY. 

The  first  Professorship  of  Chemistry  was  established  in  the  Medical  Department  (see  page  31).  When 
endowed  in  1792  under  the  will  of  William  Erving  (H.  C.  1753)1  it  was  entitled  the  Erving  Professorship 
of  Chemistry  and  Materia  Medica.  In  1816  it  became  the  Erving  Professorship  of  Chemistry,  in  1827 
the  Erving  Professorship  of  Chemistry  and  Mineralogy,  and  in  1894  the  Erving  Professorship  of 
Chemistry  again. 

1816    John  Gorham,  Erving 1827 

1827    John  White  Webster,  Erving 1850 

1850    Josiah  Parsons  Cooke,  Erving 1894 

1857  John  BsLCon,  C/niversify,  in /Ae  Medical  School 1871 

1858  Charles  William  Eliot, -<4jji>//i«/ -Pr^w^^r 1863 

1866  James  Clarke  White,  Adjunct  Prof,  in  tfie  Medical  School       .  1871 

1870  Francis  Humphreys  Storer,  Agricultural  Chemistry 

1 87 1  Charles  Loring  Jackson,  ^xj/j/aif/ /'r^xj^^r 1881

MINERALOGY   AND  GEOLOGY.  I 

The  Sturgis-Hooper  Professorship  of  Geology,  founded  by  Samuel  Hooper  in  connection  with  the 
School  of  Mming  and  Practical  Geology,  1865,  was  constituted  by  the  founder  a  separate  chair  in  1874. 

1821    ]ost^\i  Grttn  Co^^^W,  Mineralogy  and  Geology 1823 

1875  Josiah  Dwigbt  Whitney,  Sturgis- Hooper 


IN  THE  SCHOOL  OF  MINING  AND   PRACTICAL  GEOLOGY. 

The  School  was  merged  in  the  Lawrence  Scientific  School  in  1875  and  the  Sturgis-Hooper  Professor- 
ship of  Geology  was  continued  as  a  separate  chair.

NATURAL  HISTORY. 

The  Massachusetts  Professorship  of  Natural  History  was  founded  by  subscription  in  1805.  The 
Fisher  Professorship  ol  Natural  History  was  founded  in  1842,  under  the  will  of  Joshua  Fisher,  M.  D. 
(H.  C.  1766.)

ARBORICULTURE. 

The  Arnold  Professorship  of  Arboriculture  was  established  in  1879,  under  the  will  of  James  Arnold, 
who  died  in  1872. 

1879    Charles  Sprague  Sargent,  Arnold 

ANATOMY  AND   SURGERY. 

The  chair  of  Anatomy  and  Surgery,  established  in  1782,  received  in  1791  the  title  Hersey  Professor- 
ship of  Anatomy  and  Surgery,  sharing  with  the  Hersey  Professorship  of  the  Theory  and  Practice  of 
Physic  the  endowments  made  by  the  wills  of  Ezekiel  Hersey,  M.D.  (H.  C.  1728),  and  Sarah  Derby,  his 
widow,  and  the  bequest  of  Abner  Hersey,  M.  D.,  who  died  in  1793. 

1782  John  Warren,  after  1791  Hersey 1815 

1809  John  Collins  Warren,  i4/^«w/ /'r^T/SfTj^r 18 15 

18 1 5  John  Collins  Warren,  Hersey 1847 

1847  John  Collins  Warren,  Emeritus 1856 

ANATOMY. 

The  Hersey  Professorship  of  Anatomy  was  established  in  1847,  in  place  of  the  Hersey  Professorship 
of  Anatomy  and  Surgery,  being  at  the  same  time  separated  from  the  Medical  School. 

1847    Jeffries  Wyman,  Hersey 1874 

1885    Edward  Laurens  Mark,  Hersey

PROFESSORS. 

ANATOMY  AND  PHYSIOLOGY. 

The  Parkman  Professorship  of  Anatomy  and  Physiology  was  established  in  1847,  and  named  in  lionor 
of  George  Parkman,  who  gave  the  land  upon  which  the  Medical  School  was  built.  In  187 1  the  title  was 
changed  to  Parkman  Professorship  of  Anatomy.

PATHOLOGICAL  ANATOMY. 

The  Professorship  of  Pathological  Anatomy  was  endowed  by  George  Cheyne  Shattuck  in  1854,  and  re- 
ceived the  title  Shattuck  Professorship  of  Morbid  Anatomy ;  in  1879  the  title  was  changed  to  Shattuck 
Professorship  of  Pathological  Anatomy.

1887  John  Collins  Waxren,  A ssociaie  Professor  0/ Surgery     .     .     .  1893

1893  John  Collins  Warren,  Surgery 

1894  Herbert  Leslie  Burrell,  Assistant  Professor  of  Clinical  Surgery 

CLINICAL  MEDICINE. 

The  Professorship  of  Clinical  Medicine,  established  in  1854  in  place  of  the  existing  Lectureship,  was 
named  the  Jackson  Professorship  of  Clinical  Medicine  in  1858,  in  honor  of  James  Jackson,  M.  D.  (H.  C. 
1796). 

185s     George  Cheyne  Shattuck 1859 

1859    Henry  Ingersoll  Bowditch 1867 

1865     Calvin  Ellis,  Adjunct  Professor 1867 

1867    Calvin  Ellis 1883 

1884    Robert  Thaxter  Edes 1886 

1884    Edward  Newton  Whittier,  Assistant  Professor 1888 

1888  Frederick  Cheever  Shattuck 

1890  Amos  Lawrence  Mason,  Assistant  Professor 1893 

1893    Amos  Lawrence  Mason,  Associate  Professor 

THEORY  AND  PRACTICE  OF  PHYSIC. 

The  chair  established  in  1783,  received  the  title  Hersey  Professorship  of  the  Theory  and  Practice  of 
Physic  in  179T,  sharing  the  endowment  made  by  the  wills  of  Ezekiel  Hersey,  M.  D.  (H.  C.  1728),  and 
Sarah  Derby,  his  widow,  and  the  bequest  of  Abner  Hersey,  M.  D.,  who  died  in  1793. 

1783    Benjamin  Waterhouse,  Hersey 18 12

OBSTETRICS  AND  MEDICAL  JURISPRUDENCE. 

As  established  in  1815  thb  was  a  Lectureship,  but  it  was  constituted  a  Professorship  in  1818.  The 
two  subjects  were  separated  after  1877,  and  a  chair  of  Legal  Medicine  was  established  in  1889. 

1815    Walter  Channing 1854 

1854    David  Humphreys  Storer 1868 

1868    Charles  Edward  Buckingham 1877

1886  William  Lambert  Richardson,  Obstetrics 

1894  Charles  Montraville  Green,  Assist,  Prof  in  Obstetrics 

LEGAL  MEDICINE. 

1884    Frank  Winthrop  Draper,  ^xjiV/<wi/ /*r<7/3pjj^ 1889 

1889    Frank  Winthrop  Draper 

CHEMISTRY  AND  MATERIA  MEDICA. 

This  chair  was  endowed  under  the  will  of  William  Erving  in  1791,  and  received  the  name  Erving  Pro- 
fessorship of  Chemistry  and  Materia  Medica.  In  1816  it  was  divided  into  the  Erving  Professorship  of 
Chemistry  (page  27)  and  the  Lectureship  of  Materia  Medica  and  Botany,  entitled,  in  1818,  Professorship 
of  Materia  Medica. 

1783  Aaron  Dexter,  ^rz//«;^ 1816 

1809  j2LCoh  Gorhzm J  Adjunct  Prof  Chem,  and  Mat.  Med.     .     .     .  1816 

181 5  Jzcob  B\ge\o\r^  Materia  Medica 1855

ASTRONOMICAL  OBSERVATORY. 

The  Phillips  Professorship  of  Astronomy  in  the  Astronomical  Observatory  was  founded  in  1858,  under 
the  will  of  Edward  Bromlield  Phillips  (H.  C.  1845).  '^^^  Paine  Professorship  of  Practical  Astronomy 
was  foundsd  in  1887,  under  the  will  of  Robert  Treat  Paine  (H.  C.  1822).

1826    William  Parsons  Lunt,  Mathematics 1827 

1828  Ch2j\ts¥o\\%Vi,  Ethicsy  History y  and  Eccles.  Hist 1830 

1829  Francois  Marie  Joseph  Surault,  French 1838 

1831     Joel  GWcSy  Math,  and  Nat.  Philos 1831 

183 1     Thomas  Henderson,  Mathematics 1831 

t  Not  Instrurtors  regularly  appointed,  but  persons  permitted  by  the  Corporation  to  teach  such 
students  as  so  desired.  In  1766  the  students  were  forbidden  to  attend  the  instruction  of  unauthorized 
teachers,  and  the  position  of  the  licensed  teachers  became  more  defined ;  their  charges  were  included  in 
the  quarter-bills,  and  they  shared  with  the  tutors  the  privileges  of  the  Library,  of  Commons,  etc. 

40

PREACHERS   TO   THE   UNIVERSITY. 

From  1855  to  1886  the  Plummer  Professor  of  Christian  Morals  (page  22)  was  also  Preacher  to  the 

University;  since  1886  five  Preachers  to  the  University  have  been  appointed  annually.

LECTURERS. 


LECTURERS. 

The  Lectureships  in  Materia  Medica  and  Obstetrics,  founded  in  1815,  were  transformed  into  Profes- 
SQfships  in  1818.  The  Dexter  Lectureship  on  Biblical  Criticism  was  established  181 1,  under  the  will  of 
Samuel  Dexter  ;  in  1819  the  title  was  changed  to  Dexter  Professorship  of  Sacred  Literature;  in  1840,  as 
the  Dextar  Lectureship  on  Biblical  Literature,  it  was  united  with  the  Hancock  Professorship  of  Hebrew 
and  other  Oriental  Languages. 

181 1  Joseph  Stevens  Buckminster,  Z^^jr/fr 1812 

1812  William  Ellery  Channing,  Z^^jr/^r 1813 

1813  Andrews  Norton,  i?^jr/tfr 1819 

181 5    j2LCob  B\ge\ow^  Mat.  Afed,  and  Botany 1818 

18 1 5     Walter  Channing,  Obstetrics 1 81 8 

1824  ]ohn  "Whitt  y^tih^itx,  Chem,,AfineraL  and  GeoL 1826 

1825  Thomas  Nuttall,  Natnral  History 1834 

1836  Joseph  Lovering,  if/ifzM.  tf^^A''(tz/. //»/. 1838 

1837  Edward  Reynolds,  Anatomy  and  Surgery 1838 

1840     George  Rapall  Noyes,  Dexter 1868 

1847  George  Ticknor  Curtis,  Law      - 1848 

1848  Franklin  Dexter,  Z/izc' 1849

1  The  University  Lectures  were  established  in  1863,  a  course  being  given  in  each  term ;  after  1872  the 
number  of  lecturers  appointed  was  greatly  reduced,  and  the  use  of  the  word  **  University  "  in  the  title 
abandoned.    The  subjects  treated  will  be  found  in  the  Annual  Catalogues.

Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


NOTE. 


In  the  Class  lists  record  is  made  of  certain  honors  and  positions  held,  as  well  in 
the  past  as  in  the  present,  by  graduates.  The  following  paragraphs  show  concisely 
what  honors  and  positions  are  thus  recorded,  and  the  manner  in  which  they  are 
indicated.  The  order  adopted  is  that  in  which  the  facts  are  arranged  in  the  Class 
lists. 

1.  Degrees  conferred  by  other  universities,  colleges,  and  professional  schools; 

honorary  degrees,  when  a  degree  of  the  same  grade  is  generally  granted  in 
regular  course,  being  distinguished. 

The  designation  of  a  degree  is  followed  by  the  name  of  the  institution  con- 
ferring it,  and  by  the  date  of  conferment;  but  degrees  conferred  by  Harvard 
University  are  followed  by  the  date  only,  and  the  degree  of  Master  of  Arts, 
when  taken  in  course,  that  is,  three  years  after  the  date  of  the  Bachelor's 
degree,  appears  without  date. 

Graduates  who  received  their  degrees  out  of  course  are  placed  with  their 
respective  classes,  and  the  dates  when  the  degrees  were  conferred  imme- 
diately follow  the  names. 

The  completion  of  the  regular  course  at  a  professional  school  which  con- 
fers no  degree  is  indicated  by  the  name  of  the  institution  and  the  date  when 
the  course  was  completed. 

When  the  same  degree  has  been  received  from  two  or  more  institu- 
tions, the  order  of  arrangement  is  by  date;  but  with  this  exception,  that 
degrees  conferred  by  Harvard  University  are  placed  first,  without  regard  to 
chronology. 

2.  Offices  in  Harvard  University:  President;  Fellow;  Treasurer;  Overseer  (by 

election);  Professor;  Adjunct,  Associate,  and  Assistant  Professor;  Director; 
Curator;  Dean;  Tutor;  Instructor,  and  Lecturer,  if  the  appointment  is  for 
more  than  a  year;  Librarian ;  Assistant  Librarian. 

3.  Professorial  appointments  in  other   universities,  colleges,  and    professional 

schools,  provided  that  the  course  of  study  in  such  institutions  be  at  least 
equivalent  to  the  average  attainments  of  a  Harvard  undergraduate  or  profes- 
sional student  at  the  end  of  his  second  year. 

4.  Professorial  appointments  under  the   United    States  government,  or  other 

national  governments. 

5.  The  position  of  headmaster  or  prindpal  in  leading  secondary  schools,  both 

public  and  endowed,  and  the  position  of  master  in  the  same  having  charge 
of  special  departments  of  study. 

67 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


NOTE. 

6.  The  position  of  State  Superintendent  of  Public  Education,  or  whatever  officer 

corresponds  thereto,  and  that  of  Superintendent  rof  Schools  in  cities  of  not 
less  than  50,000  inhabitants. 

7.  Membership  in  foreign  national  societies  in  good  standing,  provided  such  mem- 

bership is  regarded  by  those  societies  as  an  honorable  distinction. 

8.  Membership  in  the  National  Academy  of  Sciences ;  American  Academy  of 

Arts  and  Sciences;  American  Philosophical  Society;  Massachusetts  His- 
torical Society. 

9.  Membership  other  than  resident  in  American  societies  of  the  same  grade  as 

the  foreign  societies  recognized;  the  grade  of  such  societies  to  be  determined, 
as  cases  arise,  by  a  standing  committee  of  the  University  Council. 

10.  Offices  under   the   United  States   government:    President;  Vice-President; 

President  of  the  Senate  (when  not  the  Vice-President);  Member  of  the 
Cabinet;  Senator;  Member  of  the  House  of  Representatives;  Foreign 
Minister;  Justice  and  Chief  Justice  of  the  Supreme  Court;  Judge  and  Chief 
Justice  of  the  Court  of  Claims;  Judge  of  a  Circuit  or  District  Court; 
Major-General  and  higher  ranks  (not  by  brevet) ;  Rear  Admiral  and  higher 
ranks. 

11.  Offices  under  the  State  Governments:  Governor;  Lieutenant-Governor;  Jus- 

tice and  Chief  Justice  of  the  Supreme  Court ;  also  Governors  of  Territories, 
Justice  and  Chief  Justice  of  the  Supreme  Court  in  Territories  and  in  the 
District  of  Columbia. 

12.  Offices  of  similar  grade,  and  honorary  appointments,  under  foreign  governments. 


ABBREVIATIONS. 

The  abbreviations  used  are,  in  general,  self-explanatory.  For  degrees  the  Latin 
abbreviations  are  commonly  used  (S.T.B.  =  B.D.,  S.T.D.  =D.D.),  but  the  degrees 
of  Doctor  of  Civil  Law  is  indicated  by  D.C.L.,  and  for  several  technical  degrees  the 
English  abbreviations  are  given. 

Am.  Acad.    .    .    .  American  Academy  of  Arts  and  Sciences  of  Boston. 

Am.  Philos.  See.    .  American  Philosophical  Society  of  Philadelphia. 

Div.  S Harvard  Divinity  School. 

M.C Member  of  the  House  of  Representatives  of  the 

United  States. 

M.P Member  of  Parliament  of  Great  Britain. 

Nat.  Acad.  Sci. .    .  National  Academy  of  Science  at  Washington. 

S School. 

All  who  use  the  Catalogue  are  urged  to  send  corrections,  criticisms,  and  informa- 
tion of  deaths  or  other  changes,  to  the  Editor  of  the  Quinquennial  Catalogue,  Harvard 
College  Library,  Cambridge,  Mass. 
68 


Digitized  by  VjOOQIC

The  graduates  of  1653  who  took  the  degree 
of  Bachelor  of  Arts  9  August  received  that  of 
Master  of  Arts  in  1655 ;  the  other  portion 
of  the  class,  who  took  the  Bachelor's  degree 
10  August,  were  required,  under  a  law  which 
remained  in  force  until  1873,  ^^  ^'^it  three 
years  before  taking  the  Master's  degree.

•Charles    Parker    Spalding,    M.D.

The  full  record  is  given  in  the  list  of  Bachelors  of  Arts  under  the  year  indicated.

ALUMNI  OF  THE   DIVINITY   SCHOOL  AND 
BACHELORS  OF  DIVINITY. 

S.T.B. 


*^^  A. B»,  followed  by  a  date  only,  denotes  graduation  from  Harvard  College. 
The  full  record  is  given  in  the  list  of  Bachelors  of  Arts  under  the  year  indicated 

No  degree  was  conferred  by  the  Divinity  School  before  1870,  but  the  names  of  stu- 
dents who  completed  the  regular  course  are  here  given  from  the  establishment  of  the 
School*  In  i^  the  degree  of  Bachelor  of  Theology  was  instituted^  and  after  1874  the 
names  of  those  students  only  are  given  who  received  that  degree.

Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


DOCTORS  OF  PHILOSOPHY,  DOCTORS  OF  SCIENCE,  AND 
MASTERS  OF  ARTS,  WHO  RECEIVED  THEIR  DEGREES 
AFTER  EXAMINATION. 

Ph.D.,  S.D.,  A.M. 


•»*  A, B.J  followed  by  a  date  only,  denotes  graduation  from  Harvard  College, 
The  full  record  is  given  in  the  list  of  Bachelors  of  Arts  under  the  year  indicated. 

When  more  than  one  of  these  degrees  has  been  taken  by  one  person,  not  a  grad' 
uate  of  Harvard  College,  reference  is  made  in  like  manner  to  the  full  record  under 
the  date  of  the  earliest  degree. 

The  particular  department  of  knowledge  wherein  Doctors  of  Philosophy  and 
Doctors  of  Science  obtained  their  degrees  is  indicated  immediately  after  their  names. 


1870 

A.M. 
James  McBride  Sterrett,  1894; 
A.B.  Rochester,  (N.  Y.)  1867;

Digitized  by  VjOOQIC 


HOLDERS  OF  HONORARY  DEGREES  AND  GRADUATES 
OF  OTHER  COLLEGES  WHO  HAVE  BEEN  ADMITTED 
TO  THE  SAME   DEGREE  IN   HARVARD  COLLGE.^ 


%*  A. B,y  followed  by  a  date  only^  denotes  graduation  from  Harvard  College. 
The  full  record  is  given  in  the  list  of  Bachelors  of  Arts  under  the  year  indicated. 

In  like  manner  reference  is  made  for  the  full  record  to  earlier  degrees  in  other  de- 
partments of  Harvard  University ,  or  to  earlier  degrees  in  this  list, 

•  The  degree  placed  immediately  after  the  name  is  that  conferred  by  Harvard 
College,  


1692 

•Increase    Mather,   S.T.D.;    A.B.

•Samuel  Whittelsey,  A.M.;  A.B.

•Daniel  Bliss,  A.M.;  A.B.  Yale

•i 

1742 

•Hendrick  Hans  Hansen,  A.M. ; 
A.B.  Yale  1742;  A.M.  Yale  •1755 

•i 


'  By  a  custom  now  in  disuse,  but  prevalent  during  the  eighteenth  century  and  the  first  three  decades  of 
the  nineteenth,  graduates  of  other  colleges,  particularly  Bachelors  and  Masters  of  Arts,  were  admitted, 
upon  application,  to  the  same  degree  {ad  eundem  gradum)  in  Harvard  College.  The  honorary  degrees 
which  are,  or  have  been,  granted  by  Harvard  College,  are :  Bachelor  of  Arts  ( A.B.),  Master  of  Arts  (A.M.), 
Bachelor  of  Medicine  (M.B.),  Doctor  of  Medicine  (M.D.),  Doctor  of  Dental  Medicine  (D.M.D.), 
Doctor  of  Laws  (LL.D.),  Doctor  of  Science  (S.D.),  and  Doctor  of  Divinity  (S.T.D.).

INDEX    OF    GRADUATES. 


Bachelors  of  Arts  are  indicated  by  the  date  of  graduation  only,  which  refers  to  the  Class  Lists  (p.  69),  where 
other  degrees  received  are  also  recorded.  Those  who  have  received  other  degrees,  but  not  that  of  Bachelor  of  Arts, 
from  Harvard  University,  are  distinguished  bv  italic  letters,  according  to  the  following  scheme  :  where  more  than 
one  degree  has  been  received,  reference  is  maae  to  the  one  first  laken. 


NOTE. 

Information  affecting  the  following  names  was  received  after  the  pages  of  the 
Index  had  been  cast ;  in  the  Class  lists  the  changes  have  been  made.  There  are 
a  few  cases,  not  enumerated  here,  where  an  additional  initial  should  be  inserted, 
the  full  and  correct  form  appearing  in  the  Class  lists. 


Greely^  Moses  Reuben  (1850  w) 
Green,  Frederick  Lewis  (1876)   . 
Hawkins y  Patterson  Gaylord  (1893/) 
Lindsay,  Marshall  Larkin  (1863  m)

W^<£x/Mw,  John  Moss  (1893/)     .     .     . 
Witherlee,  Charles  Bryant  (1876)   .     .
